DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

Three new coronavirus deaths were reported in King County, Washington State to bring the total number of US deaths to five. (Newswires)

WHO's Tedros said the number of coronavirus cases in China continues to decline as China reported 206 cases to the WHO yesterday which was the lowest since January 22nd and only 8 cases were reported outside Hubei province. Furthermore, he added that the epidemics in the Republic of Korea, Italy, Iran and Japan are our greatest concern but also believes Italy can still contain the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said they are to develop safe, effective vaccines and medicine as well as testing reagents for the coronavirus as soon as possible, while they are to speed up coronavirus related R&D on the basis of safety and science. (Newswires)

China Global Times Voice said if China's economy is hit too hard, it may be necessary to start weighing a large-scale stimulus package that will likely exceed the CNY 4tln (USD 574bln) plan amid the ’08 financial crisis, despite the side effects. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the US is considering tightening travel restrictions and doesn't think a national emergency declaration is needed but doesn't rule it out for the future. (Newswires)

G7 Finance Ministers are planning a call tomorrow to weigh coronavirus response and G7 central bankers will also join Tuesday’s coronavirus call with finance ministers which will be led by US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Fed Chair Powell. (Newswires)

OECD cut global economic forecast to 2.4% (Prev. 2.9%) due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Trump admin is ordering four Chinese state-owned news outlets to cut their Chinese staff in the US by about 40%, amid a broader response to Beijing’s restrictions on American journalists and the expulsion of three WSJ reporters last month. (Twitter)

PBoC issued a total of CNY 36bln via standing lending facility in which it lent CNY 33bln for 1month and CNY 3bln for 7-day via SLF in February, while the outstanding lending facility was at CNY 33bln at end Feb vs. CNY 29.24bln at end-Jan. (Newswires)

BoJ reportedly bought a record total of JPY 101.4bln of ETF on Monday. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said the problem is likely to become more significant but added that the UK is well prepared, and that the government is ready to use all levers to make sure UK is prepared for COVID19. Furthermore, PM Johnson later commented that a "significant expansion" of COVID19 in the UK is "clearly on the cards". (Newswires)

UK Government will not pass new emergency powers to fight the coronavirus until month-end and COBRA remain confident that the contagion can be managed until then, according to the Sun's Dunn. (Twitter)

UK PM Johnson spokesperson said the government is still pursuing a digital services tax with no changes made. (Newswires)

UK published trade mandate for UK/US negotiations in which it stated that the negotiating objectives set out that any future agreement must protect our NHS and uphold our high standards on food safety and animal welfare. Furthermore, the government analysis published today showed that the UK economy will benefit from a GBP 3.4bln boost as the trade deal will increase transatlantic trade flows by GBP 15.3bln. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Sunak said there is no reason to why UK and EU cannot deliver "positive findings" by June for mutual financial market access. (Newswires)

UK is ready to work with EU in a structured way on equivalence assessments and has proposed dialogue for exchange of information on equivalence, according to a letter. (Newswires)

ECB is closely monitoring developments and their implications for the economy, medium-term inflation and the transmission of our monetary policy, while it added that it stands ready to take appropriate and targeted measures, as necessary and commensurate with the underlying risks. (Newswires)

European Commission President Von der Leyen said the risk of coronavirus in EU has risen from “moderate” to “high”. (Newswires)

EU Economic Commissioner Gentolini said we will be assessing requests for fiscal flexibility under EU rules due to the coronavirus outbreak and that the EU is ready to use all policy options to safeguard growth against risks from coronavirus. (Newswires)

ECB's Wunsch said ECB does not have to act on each negative shock but must act if there is a risk of a recession, while he added that EZ recovery may be delayed a quarter or two but it is not derailed and that a V-shape recovery is not the only possible scenario. (Newswires)

ECB's VP de Guindos said the virus has added a new layer of uncertainty to global and euro area growth and that if it spreads more widely, domestic firms could be impacted via supply chain disruptions, while he added that ECB remains vigilant and data dependent and that conversations have happened with other major central banks which always takes place in times of volatility. (Newswires)

  • UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI Final (Feb) 51.7 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.9). (Newswires)
  • EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Feb) 49.2 vs. Exp. 49.1 (Prev. 49.1)

 

COMMODITIES 

Saudi Arabia reportedly plans to offer OPEC+ proposal for the group to cut 600k BPD with Saudi cutting an additional 400k BPD according to WSJ, while Saudi is said to have initially pushed for a total 1mln BPD cut but believes Russia will eventually agree to a minor cut. (Twitter)

Russia's Energy Minister Novak said Russia did not get a proposal from OPEC to jointly cut production by 1mln BPD and are evaluating earlier JTC proposal of a 600k BPD cut. Novak also said he will be attending OPEC+ meeting on March 5th-6th and noted we need to check if the meeting will still proceed amid the fears surrounding the coronavirus. (Newswires)

OPEC officials said they still plan to go ahead with their meeting this week in Vienna but a teleconference option is being discussed, according to S&P Global's Herman Wang. (Twitter)

Russia's Lukoil VP expects OPEC+ to cut output by more than 1mln BPD and stated that the coronavirus outbreak has hit oil demand but it is short term, while they expect Brent to rise above USD 60/bbl in mid-March. (Newswires)

OPEC February oil output fell 510k BPD M/M to 27.84mln BPD, with compliance at 128% (prev. 133% in Jan), amid Libyan unrest and new supply cut deal, according to a Reuters survey. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korean Leader Kim oversaw a long-range artillery drill, according to state media. (KCNA) 

 

US 

US President Trump reiterated his stance that the Fed should reduce rates and hopes the Fed is looking at stimulus. In related news, US NEC Director Kudlow and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin also reportedly favour an emergency rate cut from the Fed. (Twitter/Newswires)

Congressional sources told FBN's Lawrence there are discussions between Senator Grassley and the rest of the Senate Finance Committee about tax relief if COVID-19 starts to severely affect the US economy. (Twitter)

  • US ISM Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 50.1 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.9). (Newswires)
  • US ISM Manufacturing Prices Paid (Feb) 45.9 vs. Exp. 51.0 (Prev. 53.3)
  • US Construction Spending (Jan) M/M 1.8% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. -0.2%, Rev. 0.2%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Central bank pledges of support have helped engineer risk-on sentiment, as PMI data begins to show the impact of the virus hitting the global economy. We also have slightly more clarity on the Democrat nomination race, with Buttigieg and Klobuchar dropping out, and both set to endorse former VP Biden, adding further momentum to the centrist’s campaign after his victory in South Carolina and ahead of Super Tuesday. Meanwhile, on the data slate, US ISM manufacturing did not collapse, although some of the forward-looking metrics are a cause for concern. The European PMIs have also held up better than feared. While stocks have rallied, including a late session ramp, some note that bonds are not sharing this optimism, after yields dropped to fresh record lows (10s saw a low around 1.03%, while 30s saw yields plunge to 1.58%); analysts at Goldman Sachs noted that it is quite telling given that stocks are yielding over 2.0% though investors are still lending the US government money for 10-years at just 1%; the bank also observed that the composition of the equity rally was hardly pro-cyclical, given that (at pixel time) gains are being led by the defensive utilities and staples sectors, with energy and industrials at the bottom of the pack. Apple (AAPL) marched indices higher amid an Oppenheimer upgrade, with confidence on its strong balance sheet amid wider risk aversion, as well as wider appetite for the heavyweight. Tesla (TSLA) gapped higher on the open after weekend reports of Elliott building a stake and looking to remove CEO Dorsey. JD.com (JD) surged on a strong Q4 report; note also it announced a CFO change. Gilead (GILD) made solid gains amid its efforts to accelerate its potential coronavirus treatment, as well as acquiring Forty Seven (FTSV) for USD 4.9bln, where the latter spiked violently higher. Cruise liners’ (NCLH, CCL, RCL) woes deepened after Japanese competitor Luminous Cruise filed for bankruptcy as coronavirus weighs down demand. Verizon (VZ) was supported by an upgrade at Cowen and a positive mention in Barron’s. Airlines (UAL, AAL) were offered as more and more flight cancellations are made due to falling demand. SPX +4.58% at 3090, NDX +4.92% at 8878, DJIA +5.10% at 26,704.

The curve bull-steepened, with yields on 10s and 30s finding fresh record lows (1.03% and 1.58% respectively). Desks had also observed the interesting dynamic that Treasuries still caught a hefty bid despite risk-bouncing back after monetary and fiscal policymakers tried to assure markets with talk of support. A big part of that might be a result of dovish central bank pricing, with the implied probability of rate cuts getting boosted among major central banks. In fact, pricing was a source of interest, given that the market is nearly priced for nearly three rate cuts by the Fed's meeting on 18th March, while pricing through the end of the year now has four rate cuts pencilled in. Whether the Fed can deliver on those expectations remains to be seen, although a key focus will be Tuesday's term repo operations (which have seen oversubscriptions in recent offerings) given that the cost of borrowing overnight rose to 1.80% on Monday (above the top-end of the federal funds rate target range between 1.50-1.75%) from 1.65% on Friday. Some speculate that the Fed could tweak its offerings as an immediate way of stemming the tightening in financial conditions. US T-note futures (H0) settled 13+ ticks higher at 135-08+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 2nd MARCH 2020: Markets soothed by signs of coordinated policymaker response
content:

US MARKET WRAP 2nd MARCH 2020: Markets soothed by signs of coordinated policymaker response

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Risk-on after policymakers pledge support; ECB less enthusiastic about support measures; ISM headline not bad as some feared, details do not bode well; EZ PMIs hold up; GC rises above FFR; More clarity in Dem nomination after Buttigieg, Klobuchar drop out. 

* COMING UP: G7 COVID-19 call, RBA Monetary Policy Decision, US 'Super Tuesday', Swiss GDP (Q4), Turkish CPI, UK Construction PMI, EZ CPI (Flash).

 

* MARKET WRAP: Central bank pledges of support have helped engineer risk-on sentiment, as PMI data begins to show the impact of the virus hitting the global economy. We also have slightly more clarity on the Democrat nomination race, with Buttigieg and Klobuchar dropping out, and both set to endorse former VP Biden, adding further momentum to the centrist’s campaign after his victory in South Carolina and ahead of Super Tuesday. Meanwhile, on the data slate, US ISM manufacturing did not collapse, although some of the forward-looking metrics are a cause for concern. The European PMIs have also held up better than feared. While stocks have rallied, including a late session ramp, some note that bonds are not sharing this optimism, after yields dropped to fresh record lows (10s saw a low around 1.03%, while 30s saw yields plunge to 1.58%); analysts at Goldman Sachs noted that it is quite telling given that stocks are yielding over 2.0% though investors are still lending the US government money for 10-years at just 1%; the bank also observed that the composition of the equity rally was hardly pro-cyclical, given that (at pixel time) gains are being led by the defensive utilities and staples sectors, with energy and industrials at the bottom of the pack. Meanwhile, oil has been supported by prevailing sentiment, but it also seems that OPEC are likely to take action this week to further buttress markets (talk of Saudis taking up an additional cut of 400k, to bring the proposed total cut this week to 1mln bbls).

* CO-ORDINATED POLICY RESPONSE: Late Friday, Fed Chair Powell, in unscheduled remarks, said the coronavirus poses evolving risks to economic activity, and that the Fed was closely monitoring developments and their implications for the economic outlook, adding that it would use its "tools" and act as appropriate to support the economy. That was followed overnight by the BOJ, which in an emergency statement stated that it would provide ample liquidity and ensure stability in financial markets via repo operations -- the first since March 2016. German finance minister Scholz also said that, should the need arise, Germany has the means to act quickly and decisively to contain the virus, while Italy's economy minister announced EUR 3.6bln (0.2%/GDP) of fiscal measures. EU Commissioner Gentiloni has cast some doubt on the V-shape recovery narrative, however, stating that such a scenario might be optimistic; he also said the EU stood ready to use all policy tools to tackle the fallout from the virus. However, ECB officials have not replied to the call for support, and ECB's VP de Guindos, in addition to Governors Wunsch and Villeroy, have pushed-back on the notion the central bank would be providing any immediate support, although the usual pledges to support the economy in the event of a virus related downturn were churned out. De Guindos also confirmed that conversations had taken placed with other major central banks, given further credence to the notion of global policy coordination. Tomorrow, G-7 central bankers and finance ministers will hold a teleconference (12pmn GMT) to talk about coordinating a response to the coronavirus, sources reported. Whether policymakers will meet, exceed or disappoint market expectations (of beefy support) remains to be seen, however, some have already questioned how effective rate cuts will be to address the virus outbreak. Some have said it would at least lean back on any financial market tightening, while others suggest repo market accommodation may be more effective tool; in the latest reporting period, the GC rate had risen above the top-end of the Fed’s target range (Fed losing control of the short-end is an accusation from some traders), so there will also be attention on the Fed’s term repo operations on Tuesday (at the new reduced rate of USD 20bln), which have seen oversubscriptions in recent offerings. There is some speculation that the Fed could tweak the sizes of its operations, which may alleviate potential dollar liquidity pressures.

* COVID-19 UPDATE: Cases continue to accelerate outside of China, and some think the trend may once again be accelerating within the nation, after it announced cases were up by 575 yesterday. The global death toll is now over 3k with around 90k of confirmed cases. Looking at trend rates, the total number of global cases rose by 2.5k on Sunday, almost double the 1.3k average daily rate over the previous five days; non-China cases were up by 1.8k yesterday, again around double of the five-day trend rate. There were also reports of new cases in several US states over the weekend (including the first death in the US), and some experts warn that a surge in US cases could easily overwhelm hospitals and exacerbate supply shortages. US Vice President Pence, who is heading up the US COVID-19 response, will be holding a media briefing at 1700 ET (2200 GMT). Ahead of that, the director of infectious diseases said the US was clearly dealing with an emerging infectious disease which has breached outbreak proportions and likely pandemic proportions.

* US MANUFACTURING ISM: The headline ISM manufacturing PMI fell to 50.1 from 50.9, a bit deeper than the consensus 50.5. Prices dropped to 45.9 from 53.3 (consensus 51.0) while new orders dropped to 49.8 from 52.0. The survey has not yet captured the full fallout of the COVID outbreak, analysts said, and the report was dismissed by traders as stale, with barely any reaction in wake of the release. The employment sub-index picked up to 46.9 from the consensus expectation for an unchanged 46.6; earlier, Markit had said that its own version of the manufacturing PMI was consistent with manufacturing payrolls contracting by 20k jobs per month. "Overall, the ISM index broadly supports the other manufacturing surveys in suggesting that while the coronavirus lockdown in China was starting to have a knock-on impact on US firms via supply chain disruption, that hit has so far been relatively modest," Capital Economics said, "but with the virus continuing to spread around the world and a more serious outbreak within the US now looking increasingly likely, the disruption is likely to worsen over the coming weeks."

* US CONSUTRUCTION SPENDING: Construction spending rose 1.8% M/M in January, topping the consensus +0.6%, for the largest monthly rise since Feb 2008. The prior data also saw a healthy upward revision, which Pantheon Macroeconomics thinks will lift Q1 GDP tracking estimates, even though the COVID19 is weighing on expectations. "Most of the January action was in private homebuilding, but non-residential spending rose 0.8% too and state and local government construction jumped 2.0%," Pantheon wrote, "the construction sector, at least, 2020 got off to a flying start."

* PMI DATA: In China, the Caixin PMI in China fell to a record low, while the official manufacturing PMI also fell to a record low, and sunk at its fastest pace ever (for now, some are still placing faith in a bounce-back in the second part of the year if the virus can be contained soon, as evidenced in the future orders component within the PMI; but the labour market metrics slipped, which will take longer to normailise, while outside-China situation is worsening, clouding future foreign demand, and questioning the 'v-shape' narrative).

* COMING UP - RBA: RBA is largely expected to cut its Cash Rate to a new record low of 0.50%. Expectations for the RBA to cut have been bolstered by the dismal Chinese PMIs and volatile Fed pricing. However, rhetoric from the RBA had suggested the Central Bank is prepared to ease if needed although they are unlikely to do so just yet as was reiterated in their last meeting. Click here for full preview.

* COMING UP - SUPER TUESDAY: Former VP Joe Biden's bid to become the Democrat Presidential nominee got a shot of life, with Biden coming out on top in the South Carolina primaries, a state with a large ethnic minority. Pete Buttigieg has dropped out of the race, after his campaign did not build on early momentum. Buttigieg did not endorse another candidate immediately, although he will reportedly do so later on Monday; meanwhile, Klobuchar has also dropped out, and has endorsed Biden – analysts have suggested that these developments will, all things being equal, benefit Biden. FiveThirtyEight had earlier suggested that supporters of Buttigieg would likely send support of around 21% to Sanders, around 19% to Biden or Warren, and around 17% to Bloomberg. Billionaire Tom Steyer has also dropped out, although it makes little difference in the grand scheme of things. Some desks are also talking about a Biden/Kamale Harris ticket (Harris dropped out of the race early).

* WTI (J0) SETTLED 1.99 HIGHER AT USD 46.75; BRENT (K0) SETTLED 2.23 HIGHER AT USD 51.90: Crude markets, alongside other risk assets (read equities), made gains as US participants returned on Monday. Following the turmoil of risk appetite in the prior week, traders are now weighing if the knife has finished falling or whether we have found temporary support as oil demand could face a large shock. The growing expectations of coordinated central bank easing, alongside fiscal policy, is also likely bringing some impetus behind the bid. Furthermore, ahead of the OPEC+ meeting on March 5th/6th, Russia's Energy Minister Novak said Russia did not get a proposal from OPEC to jointly cut production by 1mln BPD and is instead evaluating the earlier JTC proposal of a 600k BPD cut. Later WSJ reports suggested Saudi Arabia plans to offer OPEC+ an additional group cut of 600k BPD, with itself cutting an 400k BPD. Interestingly, Russian corporate Lukoil later said that it expects OPEC+ to cut its output by more than 1mln BPD, although gave little further details – coming after an earlier meeting between Russia’s Kremlin and corporates ahead of the OPEC+ meeting. Elsewhere, a Reuters survey showed OPEC February oil output falling 510k BPD M/M to 27.84mln BPD, with compliance at 128% (prev. 133% in Jan), amid Libyan unrest and new supply cut deal. Looking ahead to this week’s energy inventories in the US, current expectations (bbls): crude +3.3mln, gasoline -2.1mln, distillates -1.8mln; while Genscape flyover sees Cushing stocks -1.5mln.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 13+ TICKS HIGHER AT 135-08+. The curve bull-steepened, with yields on 10s and 30s finding fresh record lows (1.03% and 1.58% respectively). Desks had also observed the interesting dynamic that Treasuries still caught a hefty bid despite risk-bouncing back after monetary and fiscal policymakers tried to assure markets with talk of support. A big part of that might be a result of dovish central bank pricing, with the implied probability of rate cuts getting boosted among major central banks. In fact, pricing was a source of interest, given that the market is nearly priced for nearly three rate cuts by the Fed's meeting on 18th March, while pricing through the end of the year now has four rate cuts pencilled in. Whether the Fed can deliver on those expectations remains to be seen, although a key focus will be Tuesday's term repo operations (which have seen oversubscriptions in recent offerings) given that the cost of borrowing overnight rose to 1.80% on Monday (above the top-end of the federal funds rate target range between 1.50-1.75%) from 1.65% on Friday. Some speculate that the Fed could tweak its offerings as an immediate way of stemming the tightening in financial conditions.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +4.58% at 3090, NDX +4.92% at 8878, DJIA +5.10% at 26,704. SECTORS: Cons Disc +3.5%, Cons Stpl +5.48%, Energy +2.95%, Financials +4.87%, Health +4.83%, Industrials +2.75%, Materials +4.15%, Real Estate +5.05%, Technology +5.7%, Communication Svs +3.59%, Utilities +5.86%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) marched indices higher amid an Oppenheimer upgrade, with confidence on its strong balance sheet amid wider risk aversion, as well as wider appetite for the heavyweight. Tesla (TSLA) gapped higher on the open after weekend reports of Elliott building a stake and looking to remove CEO Dorsey. JD.com (JD) surged on a strong Q4 report; note also it announced a CFO change. Gilead (GILD) made solid gains amid its efforts to accelerate its potential coronavirus treatment, as well as acquiring Forty Seven (FTSV) for USD 4.9bln, where the latter spiked violently higher. Cruise liners’ (NCLH, CCL, RCL) woes deepened after Japanese competitor Luminous Cruise filed for bankruptcy as coronavirus weighs down demand. Verizon (VZ) was supported by an upgrade at Cowen and a positive mention in Barron’s. Airlines (UAL, AAL) were offered as more and more flight cancellations are made due to falling demand.

* FX WRAP: The USD was sold amid risk-on conditions, with traders attributing much of the buck's fall to the strength of the EUR, where the single currency has once again retained the 1.1150 mark. The EUR gains were driven by supportive rhetoric from policymakers about the prospects of fiscal support to guard against any virus-led slowdown in the economy, while overnight demand for EURJPY was noted after the BOJ's message of support; rate differentials were also said to be playing a role, with US 10-year yields now flirting with 1%, while the long-end also saw fresh record lows Desks have talked about the EUR remaining a sell around the 1.12 area. AUD is off, despite activity currencies performing well in the risk-on environment, as pricing for rate cuts intensifies ahead of tonight's RBA meeting (25bps now expected), and while pricing for RBNZ rate cuts has also risen, the NZD is higher. Havens were also higher (USDJPY down, EURCHF down, XAU up, Treasuries up) amid talk of support from fiscal and monetary authorities, while traders still note that rate cuts will do little to improve the virus situation, which is continuing to spread outside of China. EMFX also took their cues from USD weakness, although the BRL trades weaker as more cases are reported. Commodity FX took its cue from the rally in crude prices, which has added over a couple of bucks in the front contracts. GBP could not catch a bid, however, with the EUR strength boosting EURGBP, while Brexit talks also make GBP a sell on rallies, desks have said.

* EUR: Last week's upside was largely a result of EMFX carry unwinds. This week has started off on the front foot after supportive comments from both Eurozone (including Italy) and global policymakers about taking action to stem virus fallout. Desks noted demand for EURJPY overnight after the BOJ's announcement. That said, a few desks are still sceptical about the EUR's rally in an environment where global growth is impaired. JPM's strategists said they have a bias would be to fade rallies in the 1.1090-1.1130 zone; others have suggested selling rallies near 1.12.

* AUD: After signs of global policy coordination to stem the fallout of COVID19, all eyes are on the RBA's meeting overnight, with money markets now looking for the central bank to cut rates by 25bps (desks have noted how quickly the cut pricing has gone up, given that it was still 50/50 after the recent mixed jobs data), and another cut is fully priced through the end of 2020. Reports have stated that the RBA, APRA and ASIC are holding an emergency meetings to discuss the contagion.

* GBP: the UK and EU are now in the official trade negotiations window, and in a reminder of how tense negotiations will be, Bloomberg carried a storied suggesting that Brexit trade talks could break down in weeks, according to three sources. GBP vol has firmed up and Deutsche Bank suggests that risk reversals are pointing towards further GBP downside. The bank does not think the positioning will be a problem, given that the market is still holding a small long position, and flows after last Tuesday (the cut-off date for the positioning data) has been negligible on aggregate.

US MARKET WRAP 2nd MARCH 2020: Markets soothed by signs of coordinated policymaker response

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Risk-on after policymakers pledge support; ECB less enthusiastic about support measures; ISM headline not bad as some feared, details do not bode well; EZ PMIs hold up; GC rises above FFR; More clarity in Dem nomination after Buttigieg, Klobuchar drop out. 

* COMING UP: G7 COVID-19 call, RBA Monetary Policy Decision, US 'Super Tuesday', Swiss GDP (Q4), Turkish CPI, UK Construction PMI, EZ CPI (Flash).

 

* MARKET WRAP: Central bank pledges of support have helped engineer risk-on sentiment, as PMI data begins to show the impact of the virus hitting the global economy. We also have slightly more clarity on the Democrat nomination race, with Buttigieg and Klobuchar dropping out, and both set to endorse former VP Biden, adding further momentum to the centrist’s campaign after his victory in South Carolina and ahead of Super Tuesday. Meanwhile, on the data slate, US ISM manufacturing did not collapse, although some of the forward-looking metrics are a cause for concern. The European PMIs have also held up better than feared. While stocks have rallied, including a late session ramp, some note that bonds are not sharing this optimism, after yields dropped to fresh record lows (10s saw a low around 1.03%, while 30s saw yields plunge to 1.58%); analysts at Goldman Sachs noted that it is quite telling given that stocks are yielding over 2.0% though investors are still lending the US government money for 10-years at just 1%; the bank also observed that the composition of the equity rally was hardly pro-cyclical, given that (at pixel time) gains are being led by the defensive utilities and staples sectors, with energy and industrials at the bottom of the pack. Meanwhile, oil has been supported by prevailing sentiment, but it also seems that OPEC are likely to take action this week to further buttress markets (talk of Saudis taking up an additional cut of 400k, to bring the proposed total cut this week to 1mln bbls).

* CO-ORDINATED POLICY RESPONSE: Late Friday, Fed Chair Powell, in unscheduled remarks, said the coronavirus poses evolving risks to economic activity, and that the Fed was closely monitoring developments and their implications for the economic outlook, adding that it would use its "tools" and act as appropriate to support the economy. That was followed overnight by the BOJ, which in an emergency statement stated that it would provide ample liquidity and ensure stability in financial markets via repo operations -- the first since March 2016. German finance minister Scholz also said that, should the need arise, Germany has the means to act quickly and decisively to contain the virus, while Italy's economy minister announced EUR 3.6bln (0.2%/GDP) of fiscal measures. EU Commissioner Gentiloni has cast some doubt on the V-shape recovery narrative, however, stating that such a scenario might be optimistic; he also said the EU stood ready to use all policy tools to tackle the fallout from the virus. However, ECB officials have not replied to the call for support, and ECB's VP de Guindos, in addition to Governors Wunsch and Villeroy, have pushed-back on the notion the central bank would be providing any immediate support, although the usual pledges to support the economy in the event of a virus related downturn were churned out. De Guindos also confirmed that conversations had taken placed with other major central banks, given further credence to the notion of global policy coordination. Tomorrow, G-7 central bankers and finance ministers will hold a teleconference (12pmn GMT) to talk about coordinating a response to the coronavirus, sources reported. Whether policymakers will meet, exceed or disappoint market expectations (of beefy support) remains to be seen, however, some have already questioned how effective rate cuts will be to address the virus outbreak. Some have said it would at least lean back on any financial market tightening, while others suggest repo market accommodation may be more effective tool; in the latest reporting period, the GC rate had risen above the top-end of the Fed’s target range (Fed losing control of the short-end is an accusation from some traders), so there will also be attention on the Fed’s term repo operations on Tuesday (at the new reduced rate of USD 20bln), which have seen oversubscriptions in recent offerings. There is some speculation that the Fed could tweak the sizes of its operations, which may alleviate potential dollar liquidity pressures.

* COVID-19 UPDATE: Cases continue to accelerate outside of China, and some think the trend may once again be accelerating within the nation, after it announced cases were up by 575 yesterday. The global death toll is now over 3k with around 90k of confirmed cases. Looking at trend rates, the total number of global cases rose by 2.5k on Sunday, almost double the 1.3k average daily rate over the previous five days; non-China cases were up by 1.8k yesterday, again around double of the five-day trend rate. There were also reports of new cases in several US states over the weekend (including the first death in the US), and some experts warn that a surge in US cases could easily overwhelm hospitals and exacerbate supply shortages. US Vice President Pence, who is heading up the US COVID-19 response, will be holding a media briefing at 1700 ET (2200 GMT). Ahead of that, the director of infectious diseases said the US was clearly dealing with an emerging infectious disease which has breached outbreak proportions and likely pandemic proportions.

* US MANUFACTURING ISM: The headline ISM manufacturing PMI fell to 50.1 from 50.9, a bit deeper than the consensus 50.5. Prices dropped to 45.9 from 53.3 (consensus 51.0) while new orders dropped to 49.8 from 52.0. The survey has not yet captured the full fallout of the COVID outbreak, analysts said, and the report was dismissed by traders as stale, with barely any reaction in wake of the release. The employment sub-index picked up to 46.9 from the consensus expectation for an unchanged 46.6; earlier, Markit had said that its own version of the manufacturing PMI was consistent with manufacturing payrolls contracting by 20k jobs per month. "Overall, the ISM index broadly supports the other manufacturing surveys in suggesting that while the coronavirus lockdown in China was starting to have a knock-on impact on US firms via supply chain disruption, that hit has so far been relatively modest," Capital Economics said, "but with the virus continuing to spread around the world and a more serious outbreak within the US now looking increasingly likely, the disruption is likely to worsen over the coming weeks."

* US CONSUTRUCTION SPENDING: Construction spending rose 1.8% M/M in January, topping the consensus +0.6%, for the largest monthly rise since Feb 2008. The prior data also saw a healthy upward revision, which Pantheon Macroeconomics thinks will lift Q1 GDP tracking estimates, even though the COVID19 is weighing on expectations. "Most of the January action was in private homebuilding, but non-residential spending rose 0.8% too and state and local government construction jumped 2.0%," Pantheon wrote, "the construction sector, at least, 2020 got off to a flying start."

* PMI DATA: In China, the Caixin PMI in China fell to a record low, while the official manufacturing PMI also fell to a record low, and sunk at its fastest pace ever (for now, some are still placing faith in a bounce-back in the second part of the year if the virus can be contained soon, as evidenced in the future orders component within the PMI; but the labour market metrics slipped, which will take longer to normailise, while outside-China situation is worsening, clouding future foreign demand, and questioning the 'v-shape' narrative).

* COMING UP - RBA: RBA is largely expected to cut its Cash Rate to a new record low of 0.50%. Expectations for the RBA to cut have been bolstered by the dismal Chinese PMIs and volatile Fed pricing. However, rhetoric from the RBA had suggested the Central Bank is prepared to ease if needed although they are unlikely to do so just yet as was reiterated in their last meeting. Click here for full preview.

* COMING UP - SUPER TUESDAY: Former VP Joe Biden's bid to become the Democrat Presidential nominee got a shot of life, with Biden coming out on top in the South Carolina primaries, a state with a large ethnic minority. Pete Buttigieg has dropped out of the race, after his campaign did not build on early momentum. Buttigieg did not endorse another candidate immediately, although he will reportedly do so later on Monday; meanwhile, Klobuchar has also dropped out, and has endorsed Biden – analysts have suggested that these developments will, all things being equal, benefit Biden. FiveThirtyEight had earlier suggested that supporters of Buttigieg would likely send support of around 21% to Sanders, around 19% to Biden or Warren, and around 17% to Bloomberg. Billionaire Tom Steyer has also dropped out, although it makes little difference in the grand scheme of things. Some desks are also talking about a Biden/Kamale Harris ticket (Harris dropped out of the race early).

* WTI (J0) SETTLED 1.99 HIGHER AT USD 46.75; BRENT (K0) SETTLED 2.23 HIGHER AT USD 51.90: Crude markets, alongside other risk assets (read equities), made gains as US participants returned on Monday. Following the turmoil of risk appetite in the prior week, traders are now weighing if the knife has finished falling or whether we have found temporary support as oil demand could face a large shock. The growing expectations of coordinated central bank easing, alongside fiscal policy, is also likely bringing some impetus behind the bid. Furthermore, ahead of the OPEC+ meeting on March 5th/6th, Russia's Energy Minister Novak said Russia did not get a proposal from OPEC to jointly cut production by 1mln BPD and is instead evaluating the earlier JTC proposal of a 600k BPD cut. Later WSJ reports suggested Saudi Arabia plans to offer OPEC+ an additional group cut of 600k BPD, with itself cutting an 400k BPD. Interestingly, Russian corporate Lukoil later said that it expects OPEC+ to cut its output by more than 1mln BPD, although gave little further details – coming after an earlier meeting between Russia’s Kremlin and corporates ahead of the OPEC+ meeting. Elsewhere, a Reuters survey showed OPEC February oil output falling 510k BPD M/M to 27.84mln BPD, with compliance at 128% (prev. 133% in Jan), amid Libyan unrest and new supply cut deal. Looking ahead to this week’s energy inventories in the US, current expectations (bbls): crude +3.3mln, gasoline -2.1mln, distillates -1.8mln; while Genscape flyover sees Cushing stocks -1.5mln.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 13+ TICKS HIGHER AT 135-08+. The curve bull-steepened, with yields on 10s and 30s finding fresh record lows (1.03% and 1.58% respectively). Desks had also observed the interesting dynamic that Treasuries still caught a hefty bid despite risk-bouncing back after monetary and fiscal policymakers tried to assure markets with talk of support. A big part of that might be a result of dovish central bank pricing, with the implied probability of rate cuts getting boosted among major central banks. In fact, pricing was a source of interest, given that the market is nearly priced for nearly three rate cuts by the Fed's meeting on 18th March, while pricing through the end of the year now has four rate cuts pencilled in. Whether the Fed can deliver on those expectations remains to be seen, although a key focus will be Tuesday's term repo operations (which have seen oversubscriptions in recent offerings) given that the cost of borrowing overnight rose to 1.80% on Monday (above the top-end of the federal funds rate target range between 1.50-1.75%) from 1.65% on Friday. Some speculate that the Fed could tweak its offerings as an immediate way of stemming the tightening in financial conditions.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +4.58% at 3090, NDX +4.92% at 8878, DJIA +5.10% at 26,704. SECTORS: Cons Disc +3.5%, Cons Stpl +5.48%, Energy +2.95%, Financials +4.87%, Health +4.83%, Industrials +2.75%, Materials +4.15%, Real Estate +5.05%, Technology +5.7%, Communication Svs +3.59%, Utilities +5.86%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) marched indices higher amid an Oppenheimer upgrade, with confidence on its strong balance sheet amid wider risk aversion, as well as wider appetite for the heavyweight. Tesla (TSLA) gapped higher on the open after weekend reports of Elliott building a stake and looking to remove CEO Dorsey. JD.com (JD) surged on a strong Q4 report; note also it announced a CFO change. Gilead (GILD) made solid gains amid its efforts to accelerate its potential coronavirus treatment, as well as acquiring Forty Seven (FTSV) for USD 4.9bln, where the latter spiked violently higher. Cruise liners’ (NCLH, CCL, RCL) woes deepened after Japanese competitor Luminous Cruise filed for bankruptcy as coronavirus weighs down demand. Verizon (VZ) was supported by an upgrade at Cowen and a positive mention in Barron’s. Airlines (UAL, AAL) were offered as more and more flight cancellations are made due to falling demand.

* FX WRAP: The USD was sold amid risk-on conditions, with traders attributing much of the buck's fall to the strength of the EUR, where the single currency has once again retained the 1.1150 mark. The EUR gains were driven by supportive rhetoric from policymakers about the prospects of fiscal support to guard against any virus-led slowdown in the economy, while overnight demand for EURJPY was noted after the BOJ's message of support; rate differentials were also said to be playing a role, with US 10-year yields now flirting with 1%, while the long-end also saw fresh record lows Desks have talked about the EUR remaining a sell around the 1.12 area. AUD is off, despite activity currencies performing well in the risk-on environment, as pricing for rate cuts intensifies ahead of tonight's RBA meeting (25bps now expected), and while pricing for RBNZ rate cuts has also risen, the NZD is higher. Havens were also higher (USDJPY down, EURCHF down, XAU up, Treasuries up) amid talk of support from fiscal and monetary authorities, while traders still note that rate cuts will do little to improve the virus situation, which is continuing to spread outside of China. EMFX also took their cues from USD weakness, although the BRL trades weaker as more cases are reported. Commodity FX took its cue from the rally in crude prices, which has added over a couple of bucks in the front contracts. GBP could not catch a bid, however, with the EUR strength boosting EURGBP, while Brexit talks also make GBP a sell on rallies, desks have said.

* EUR: Last week's upside was largely a result of EMFX carry unwinds. This week has started off on the front foot after supportive comments from both Eurozone (including Italy) and global policymakers about taking action to stem virus fallout. Desks noted demand for EURJPY overnight after the BOJ's announcement. That said, a few desks are still sceptical about the EUR's rally in an environment where global growth is impaired. JPM's strategists said they have a bias would be to fade rallies in the 1.1090-1.1130 zone; others have suggested selling rallies near 1.12.

* AUD: After signs of global policy coordination to stem the fallout of COVID19, all eyes are on the RBA's meeting overnight, with money markets now looking for the central bank to cut rates by 25bps (desks have noted how quickly the cut pricing has gone up, given that it was still 50/50 after the recent mixed jobs data), and another cut is fully priced through the end of 2020. Reports have stated that the RBA, APRA and ASIC are holding an emergency meetings to discuss the contagion.

* GBP: the UK and EU are now in the official trade negotiations window, and in a reminder of how tense negotiations will be, Bloomberg carried a storied suggesting that Brexit trade talks could break down in weeks, according to three sources. GBP vol has firmed up and Deutsche Bank suggests that risk reversals are pointing towards further GBP downside. The bank does not think the positioning will be a problem, given that the market is still holding a small long position, and flows after last Tuesday (the cut-off date for the positioning data) has been negligible on aggregate.

Daily FX Wrap: Usd/majors mostly weaker in line with manufacturing PMI and ISM
content:
DXY

Already hyped up March FOMC easing expectations have been marked even higher in wake of US manufacturing surveys showing a downward revisions to the headline PMI at 50.7 from a prelim 50.8, but more so when the ISM missed consensus at 50.1 and components like prices paid and new orders tumbled through the key 50.0 threshold. Indeed, -75 bp is now the minimum anticipated and the probability of a full point cut in the Fed Funds rate is nearing 25%, leaving the DXY hovering around 97.500, albeit off worst levels within a 98.087-97.296 range as currency markets continue to weigh up exactly how much and coordinated the global response to China’s coronavirus might be.

EUR/CHF

The biggest beneficiaries of Dollar weakness, but both also gleaning traction from ECB speakers pushing back on an immediate reaction to the aforementioned COVID-19 outbreak given that the SNB will be influenced, though not beholden to any further easing/stimulus from the former. Eur/Usd has now reclaimed 1.1100+ status after breaching the 200 DMA (1.1098) and Usd/Chf has retreated through 0.9600 again as Eur/Chf hovers around 1.0650.

AUD/JPY

The next best G10s, as the Aussie draws momentum from a firmer Yuan and heightened perceptions that the PBoC and/or Chinese Government will be compelled to take more action following extremely dire PMIs. Aud/Usd is comfortably over 0.6500 as Usd/Cnh pares back from 7.0000 and attention turns to the RBA to see whether the OCR is lowered by 25 bp as unanimously anticipated – for a detailed preview of the policy meeting see the Newsquawk Research Suite. Meanwhile, the BoJ has already rolled out more QE as the number of nCoV cases and fatalities in Japan rises, but Usd/Jpy has bounced firmly within 107.00-108.57 parameters against the backdrop of significantly less risk aversion, albeit in very volatile trade overall at the start of the new week and month.

NZD/CAD

Both narrowly mixed vs their US counterpart as the Kiwi marginally lagged its Aussie peer, but managed to hold above 0.6500 and 1.0500 respectively, while the Loonie defended 1.3400, partly due to a rebound in crude prices and pick up in Canada’s manufacturing PMI.

GBP

The Pound has kicked off March on a weaker footing across the board amidst Brexit jitters going in to trade talks between the UK and EU, the publication of Britain’s mandate for negotiations with the US and as the BoE promised to take all steps needed to protect stability. Cable relinquished 1.2800 and Eur/Gbp climbed above 0.8700 to test offers/resistance ahead of the 200 DMA (0.8744) and Sterling never really recovered after a marginal downgrade to the UK manufacturing PMI.

EM 

Hectic Monday trade for many regional currencies amidst several swings in sentiment, manufacturing PMIs and for the Rub and Try ongoing efforts to resolve differences over Syria’s Idlib. However, the Zar took some solace from Eskom not experiencing rotational load-shedding today and consolidation/short covering after last week’s extreme depreciation and underperformance.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: hairy start to March continues
content: Manic Monday market moves show little sign of abating, as participants ponder whether more global Central Banks and Governments will follow in the footsteps of China and deliver policy responses to counteract the economic fallout from the nCoV epidemic. Bonds remain relatively firm, albeit well off best levels, while the Dollar recent saw losses stack up against the Euro especially before rebounding sharply amidst ECB commentary via de Guindos and Wunsch, both playing down knee-jerk reaction to the COVID-19 contagion, but latter confirming that monetary authorities have been in contact about recent price volatility. Eur/Usd squeezed up to 1.1160+, but is now back down around 1.1115 as the DXY reclaims 97.500+ vs 97.296 at one stage. Ahead, Canadian PMI kicks off the pm agenda that culminates in US ISM.

  • Twitter, Inc. (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has had a large stake bought in it by activist investor Paul Singer’s Elliott Management
  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has been upgraded to Outperform from Perform at Oppenheimer
  • The Trump administration is mulling invoking special powers (Defense Production Act) to ramp up production of protective masks and clothing amid the virus

2nd March 2020

  • In this week’s Barron’s publication, Berkshire (BRK.A), Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), and Apple (AAPL) were mentioned positively due to their strong balance sheets amid the virus, and defensive names in respective sectors were praised such as Verizon Communications (VZ) in telecom, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) in banking, Comcast (CMCSA) in television, and Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP) in energy. Elsewhere, PacWest Bancorp (PACW), Umpqua Holdings (UMPQ) and KeyCorp (KEY) were mentioned as strong dividend providers amid regional bank underperformance.
  • The Trump administration is mulling invoking special powers (Defense Production Act) to ramp up production of protective masks and clothing amid the virus – of note for Honeywell (HON), 3M (MMM), Kimberly-Clark (KMB) and Alpha Pro Tech (APT). Meanwhile, Honeywell has said it will boost protective mask production.

DOW

  • American Express Co (AXP) (Financials/Consumer Finance) has reportedly been misleading small business owners to raise its card sign-ups after its Costco (CSCO) partnership expired, WSJ reports; AXP has said only a small amount of cases are “inconsistent with our sales policies”.
  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has been upgraded to Outperform from Perform at Oppenheimer with a USD 320 PT (shares last closed at 273.36), where analyst Andrew Uerkwitz cites its resilience in uncertainty, strong balance sheet and its position as a “recurring revenue machine”, believing near-term that iPhone production shifts will prove transitory. Elsewhere, MacRumors reports, citing analyst Ming-Chi Kuo, that iPhone production won’t significantly improve before Q2 as suppliers struggle to uphold output.
  • Nike (NKE) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) has closed its European HQ in Netherlands on Monday and Tuesday after an employee has been infected with the virus.
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Lilly (Eli) & Co. (LLY) have announced sBLA approval by the FDA for tanezumab 2.5mg, an osteoarthritis-related treatment.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) has appointed Jamie Iannone as COO for US e-commerce, who has been recently running operations at its Sam’s Club unit. Elsewhere, the Co and Verizon Communications (VZ) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) are in discussions to bring 5G internet services to Walmart retail locations, which would power its proposed new digital health services, according to WSJ sources.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has cancelled its large internal Las Vegas meeting in March due to the virus.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is laying off “at least” 3,200 delivery drivers, BuzzFeed reports, although adds that it is still growing its delivery driver network, hiring smaller contractors. Elsewhere, Economic Times reports that the Co plans to launch its Indian food delivery service in March with a restaurant commission charge of between 10-15%, approximately half of what competitors Swiggy and Zomato charge.
  • American Airlines Group (AAL) (Industrials/Airlines) is waving changing fees on newly purchased tickets amid the virus; Co has also suspended all flights to Milan.
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology), as previously sources reports suggested, will acquire Forty Seven (FTSV) for USD 4.9bln, or USD 95.50/shr, in an all cash transaction.
  • JD.com Inc (JD) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) Q4 19: Adj. EPS RMB 0.54 (perv. RMB0.51), Revenue RMB 170.7bln (prev. RMB134.8bln). CFO Sidney Huang is to step down in September, where current Senior VP and CFO of JD Retail, Sandy Xu, will succeed.
  • NXP Semiconductors NV (NXPI) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) updated its Q1 Revenue view, saying it will likely be lower than previously guided due to the coronavirus. Co says it has already had a USD 50mln Revenue impact, which if sustained could rise to USD 150mln.
  • United Continental Holdings (UAL) (Industrials/Airlines) CEO Oscar Munoz has emailed employees saying additional flights would likely need to be cut as demand falls. Co has also delayed its investor day to September from March 5th.

S&P 500

  • AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) says its Phase 3 trial of venetoclax in combination with cytarabine, vs. LDAC in combo with placebo, for treatment of myeloid leukemia did not reach its primary endpoints.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) has been upgraded to Neutral from Underweight by noted JPMorgan analyst/bear Stephen Tusa, raising his PT to USD 8 from 5 (shares last closed at 10.88), saying “we were wrong” and that the floor on the Co’s FCF estimate is higher than expected.
  • Harley-Davidson (HOG) (Consumer Discretionary/Motorcycle Manufacturers) CEO Matthew Levatich has stepped down from the position as well as the board, existing board member Jochen Zeitz will takeover the role while the Co searches for a successor.
  • Twitter, Inc. (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has had a large stake bought in it by activist investor Paul Singer’s Elliott Management, which is reportedly seeking a removal of CEO Dorsey, believing his attention is focused elsewhere, namely running Square Inc (SQ) (Information Technology/IT Services) and desires to move to Africa.

OTHER

  • Wayfair Inc (W) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) – Short seller Andrew Left said he closed out his 4-year short position in the retailer after its tumble lower on Friday post earnings.

subject: ECB's Wunsch says ECB does not have to act on each negative shock but must act if there is a risk of a recession, EZ recovery may be delayed a quarter or two but it is not derailed. V-shape recovery is not the only possible scenario
content:
• Must be very vigilant about coronavirus as inflation is already well below target
  • Low and negative rates allows for a fiscal response in an emergency
  • My plea, however, is that we should not rush to fire our remaining fiscal ammunition. The euro economy is not in recession and jobs are still being created.
  • Purchasing manager indices has indicated "that there has been positive underlying momentum in the euro economy"
  • Because of the corona virus, growth could now be lower than previously assumed by the ECB

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment was volatile in APAC hours on the abysmal Chinese PMIs; however, did recover throughout the Asia session before reverting back into negative territory in EU trade
  • BoJ said it will closely monitor future developments and offered to buy JPY 500bln of JGBs & reportedly bought a record total of JPY 101.4bln of ETF on Monday
  • EU Economic Commissioner Gentiloni says we will be assessing requests for fiscal flexibility under EU rules due to the coronavirus outbreak
  • OECD cuts global economic forecast on virus to 2.4% (Prev. 2.9%); China 4.9% (Prev. 6.1%), US 1.9% (Prev. 2.3%), EZ 0.8% (Prev. 1.2%)
  • Russia's Energy Minister Novak says Russia did not get a proposal from OPEC to jointly cut production by 1mln BPD, evaluating earlier JTC proposal of 600k BPD cut; Putin has been supportive to working with OPEC
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Manufacturing PMI (Final), US ISM Manufacturing PMI, Construction Spending and ECB’s de Guindos

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

OECD cuts global economic forecast on virus to 2.4% (Prev. 2.9%); China 4.9% (Prev. 6.1%), US 1.9% (Prev. 2.3%), EZ 0.8% (Prev. 1.2%)

European Commission President Von der Leyen says the risk of coronavirus in EU has risen from “moderate” to “high”. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li says the coronavirus outbreak control remains at a crucial stage, there is a positive trend in areas outside Hubei, but strict prevention and control measures must be maintained. (Newswires)

China reported 202 additional coronavirus cases and 42 additional deaths as of March 1st vs. Prev. 573 additional cases and 35 additional deaths on February 29th. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 599 more cases of coronavirus and 2 more deaths to bring the total number of cases to 4335 and death toll at 22, while Indonesia confirmed 2 coronavirus cases. (Newswires)

European Commissions' Kyriakides said there are 2100 coronavirus cases in 18 EU members states. as of this morning 38 EU citizens died from coronavirus. (Newswires)

Italy reported it now has 1694 confirmed coronavirus cases vs. Prev. 1128 and its death toll rose to a total of 34 from Prev. 29. In related news, France reported 30 new coronavirus cases to increase the total to 130, while the German government crisis committee called on cancellations of imminent major international events and conferences, as well as intensifying cross-border measures; cases in Germany now stand at 150. (Newswires)

US confirmed the first 2 coronavirus-related deaths which were both in Washington State and New York State also confirmed its 1st positive coronavirus test. Furthermore, officials cautioned that more will come and noted increasing indications coronavirus has been spreading undetected in a suburb of Seattle city for weeks, while Florida reportedly declared a public health emergency after 2 people tested presumptively positive for coronavirus. (Newswires)

US President Trump is to meet with drug companies on Monday to discuss progress on coronavirus vaccines, while it was also reported that US VP Pence will hold a briefing regarding coronavirus at 1700EST today. (Newswires)

US House of Representatives members are reportedly being advised to put plans in place for office operations in the event of widespread COVID-19 infections in the US and House of Representatives could vote on emergency COVID-19 bill as soon as this week. (Washington Post/Newswires)

US Health Secretary Azar said closing some schools is possible but it depends on the circumstances and that they do not yet have a "definitive link" on how California patient contracted the virus but doesn't think it was related to the air base repatriation effort. In related news. Acting White House Budget Office Chief Vought said we will need supplemental funding shortly but have not run out of money. (Newswires)

Australia confirm the first community transmission of the coronavirus, according to the New South Wales State Government. Australian Treasurer Frydenberg said they are prepared economically to deal with challenges posed by the coronavirus and noted that a fiscal response will be considered, responsible and targeted, while it was also reported that New Zealand PM Ardern extended travel restrictions for 7-days on China and Iran. (Newswires)

BoE said it’s working with the Treasury as well as international partners “to ensure all necessary steps are taken to protect financial and monetary stability” amid the coronavirus. (Newswires) UK PM Johnson is to chair a Cobra committee meeting later in which Senior Ministers and Health Advisors will be told that the coronavirus outbreak will present a “significant challenge” as the UK’s count reached 36 confirmed cases from 23 a day earlier. (BBC)

EU Economic Commissioner Gentiloni says we will be assessing requests for fiscal flexibility under EU rules due to the coronavirus outbreak; EU is ready to use all policy options to safeguard growth against risks from coronavirus; coordinated response should be timely. It is still too soon to measure the impact from the coronavirus outbreak, probable "V-shaped" recovery cannot be taken for granted. Additionally, will consider Italy's request for fiscal flexibility as part of the spirit of solidarity due to the coronavirus. (Newswires) Follows reports that Italy will introduce measures valued at EUR 3.6bln to support the economy amid the coronavirus outbreak. For reference, this is on top of EUR 900mln pledged on Friday. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire said that the coronavirus will have a much bigger effect on the domestic economy vs. the 0.1% forecast until now; too early to provide a new growth forecast - will be concerted action between Gov't to support the economy. (Newswires) ECB's Villeroy said so far, the virus outbreak is not having a generalised impact on consumer demand, policy is already very accommodative. (Newswires)

EU Commissioner for Internal Markets Breton said that the coronavirus has impacted European tourism revenue by EUR 1bln per month since the outbreak began. (Newswires)

Three Public Health Officials have described the coronavirus outbreak as a pandemic. (FT). SCMP article noted that a critically ill Chinese patient with coronavirus was saved by stem cell therapy. (SCMP)

ASIA-PAC

Asian bourses and US equity futures began the week volatile with hefty losses seen at the reopen as markets reacted to the abysmal Chinese Manufacturing PMI data over the weekend which slumped to below GFC levels and its weakest on record. This saw US equity futures drop by as much as 3% although later recouped all their losses as markets found reprieve from the declining pace of China’s coronavirus cases and amid widespread anticipation of Central Bank measures including calls for the Fed to deliver a 50bps cut at this month’s meeting. ASX 200 (-0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were mixed in which Australia suffered from its heavy exposure to China and with financials also weighed by expectations of a rate cut by the RBA tomorrow, while the Japanese benchmark staged a comeback helped by the BoJ which is to ensure liquidity through operations and offered to buy JPY 500bln of JGBs. Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+3.2%) were also positive despite the alarming Chinese PMI data in which both China’s Official and Caixin Manufacturing PMIs fell to record lows, as sentiment was underpinned by measures including China permitting SMEs to delay debt repayments and with construction stocks surging on anticipation of China rushing into infrastructure projects to offset the fallout to the economy from the outbreak. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded positive but were off their intraday highs as the turnaround in stocks eventually dampened safe-haven appetite, although JGBs still remained afloat after the BoJ declared it will ensure ample liquidity and received JPY 571bln of total bids for the aforementioned JPY 500bln offer.

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9811 vs. Exp. 6.9808 (Prev. 7.0066) PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 35.7 vs. Exp. 46.0 (Prev. 50.0). (Newswires) Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 29.6 vs. Exp. 50.0 (Prev. 54.1) Chinese Composite PMI (Feb) 28.9 (Prev. 53.0)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 40.3 vs. Exp. 45.7 (Prev. 51.1)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said they are seeing unstable moves in markets and will strive to provide ample liquidity, while he added they are to ensure liquidity through operations and asset purchases. Furthermore, the BoJ said it will closely monitor future developments and offered to buy JPY 500bln of JGBs for March 3rd-16th. (Newswires) BoJ reportedly bought a record total of JPY 101.4bln of ETF on Monday. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

UK Trade Mandate for US talks has been published, largely in-line with expectations and prev. reports into this. Prior to this, UK PM Johnson said he will drive a hard bargain regarding trade talks with US and reiterated that the NHS will not be up for discussion. UK PM Johnson has been warned that he faces a “big choice” between following EU or US standards as Minister will today reveal what they seek in a US/UK trade deal, with talks between the two sides expected to begin this month. (Sky News/Guardian)

Observers in Brussels actually think the UK is 'closer to the Political Declaration and a likely landing zone than No.10 want people to think', according to Express’ Barnes citing sources. (Twitter)

UK Trade Secretary Truss states that we will achieve a trade deal with the EU that does not require selling out of our fishing; will not diminish food safety standards or out the NHS on the table in a US deal. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Sunak is planning to scrap a GBP 3bln tax relief in a bid to raise cash for an expected increase in public spending as he sets out the budget on 11th March. (Guardian)

German Finance Minister Scholz stated that the Finance Ministry is looking into ways of loosening the debt brake; however, the Finance Ministry have stated there is no change needed on the debt brake. (Handelsblatt/Newswires)

French President Macron has reportedly warned EU leaders that a failure to win a good post-Brexit deal for European fishermen would trigger civil unrest. French Ministers have also been told that protests and blockades of ports would commence 24hrs of European boats being excluded from UK fishing waters. (Times) France’s European Affairs Minister Amélie de Montchalin suggested that trade talks could collapse due to fishing rights. Additionally, reports note that red-lines between the two parties could place the chances of an agreement in question by early-April (Politics Home/Newswires)

ECB's Makhlouf said he would support adjusting the core inflation target of “below but close to 2%” into a range such as 1.8%-2.2%. Makhlouf also called for the cost of housing to be given more weight in the EZ inflation calculation. (FT)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Feb) 49.2 vs. Exp. 49.1 (Prev. 49.1)

-        German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 48.0 vs. Exp. 47.8 (Prev. 47.8)

-        French Markit Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 49.8 vs. Exp. 49.7 (Prev. 49.7)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI Final (Feb) 51.7 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.9)

EQUITIES

European stocks have given up their earlier gains [Eurostoxx 50 -1.3%] which initially emanated from Central Bank stimulus hopes given the concoction of dismal PMIs from China coupled with rising worldwide COVID19 cases. The European bellwether rose as much as 2.3% at the open before the optimistic sentiment faded during mid-trade with a lack of any fresh headlines to shadow the ongoing virus narrative. DAX 30 cash and futures briefly reclaimed 12k whilst the FTSE MIB (-3.1%) underperforms the region following another sharp rise in virus cases in the country alongside disappointing manufacturing PMI figures. Sector-wise, dropping yields see financials underperforming whilst defensives remain in firm positive territory amid the turnaround in sentiment. That said, energy and material names continue to benefit from the price action in the respective complexes. In terms of individual movers, Tesco (+2.0%) holds onto a bulk of its gains following a WSJ report that a Thai billionaire has secured USD 10bln in a bid to acquire Co’s Asian assets. SES (-17%) shares slumped to foot of the Stoxx 600 post-earnings despite noting that it sees no meaningful impact from coronavirus. Finally, Nokia (+1.6%) shares opened higher after Lundmark has been appointed as President and CEO of the Co.

FX

USD - The DXY has retreated even further amidst broad Greenback losses and growing speculation that the Fed will follow/front run other global Central Banks with decisive action to counter the nCoV epidemic. Indeed, expectations were stoked further by unexpected and unscheduled comments from Powell on Friday pledging to use ‘tools’ as required to support the US economy given risks posed by the aforementioned coronavirus outbreak. Rate cut pricing duly ramped up to 50 bp for the upcoming March FOMC and the index has now slipped below the 200 DMA (97.840) to a 97.693 low compared to 98.087 at best with little in the way left in terms of chart support ahead of 97.500.

AUD/EUR/CAD/CHF/NZD/JPY - Although the RBA is widely tipped to shave its OCR by ¼ point overnight, the Aussie is benefiting from US and NZ underperformance, while gleaning extra traction from relative Yuan strength on the premise that Chinese PMIs were so bad that more stimulus is almost certain to be forthcoming. Indeed, Aud/Usd has rebounded strongly from even deeper sub-0.6500 lows to 0.6550+ at one stage, while Usd/Cnh is back down around 9.9600 and Nzd/Usd is hovering just under 0.6275 as Aud/Nzd pivots 1.0450. Elsewhere, the Loonie has pared losses from circa 1.3445 to around 1.3340 ahead of Canada’s manufacturing PMI, the Franc is eyeing 0.9600, but waning against the Euro ahead of 1.0625 as the single currency forges more pronounced gains across the board, Eur/Usd towards 1.1100 and Eur/Gbp approaching 0.8700. Last, but by no means least the Yen is holding within a wide 107.00-108.57 range after the BoJ’s own considerable efforts to combat the adverse economic impact of COVID-19.

GBP/NOK/SEK - Sterling is bucking the overall trend, with Cable losing grip of another big figure handle at 1.2800 on the cusp of UK-EU trade talks that are not expected to go smoothly given well documented differences of opinion on key post-Brexit terms and conditions. However, a downgrade to the manufacturing PMI has also dented sentiment, in contrast to Norwegian and Swedish prints that both picked up pace from previous levels. Nevertheless, Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek are trading on a mixed footing circa 10.3800 and 10.5800 respectively.

EM - In keeping with the divergence noted above, regional currencies are somewhat betwixt and between as euphoria over the prospect of concerted and/or coordinated action to spur global growth fades, while the Lira is still anxiously eyeing events in Syria where Turkish President Erdogan renews calls for Government forces to withdraw or face more military attacks.

Goldman Sachs sees 50bps cut from the Fed by March 18th and another 50bps cut in Q2, while it also sees most other G10 central banks lowering rates as well. (Newswires) 

FIXED

An extremely lively start to the new week/month for debt markets, but ultimately more upside for Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries, with the former also deriving momentum from another downturn in BTPs following Italy’s fiscal package to offset the damage from nCoV. The 10 year benchmarks have been up to 178.38, 136.22 and 135-24+ respectively, as expectations continue to build for multi-pronged stimulus, but fail to sustain riskier assets and keep curves on a steepening trajectory overall. Ahead, final US Markit manufacturing PMI provides the appetiser for ISM.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent font-month futures have rebounded with a vengeance on the first trading session of the week as sentiment was bolstered amid hopes of monetary and fiscal intervention to deal with the fallout of the virus. Furthermore, OPEC will publish its latest output policy decision on March 6th as planned as per sources – with Russia seemingly on board for a unison response following comments from Russian President Putin. That being said, Putin caveated that the current oil prices are acceptable for Russia’s budget, whilst Kremlin stated the meeting with Russian oil companies were not aimed at taking any specific decision. Russia's Energy Minister Novak stated that Russia did not get a proposal from OPEC to jointly cut production by 1mln BPD and are evaluating the earlier JTC proposal of 600k BPD cut. Futures opened lower to the tune of over 2.5% amid dismal Chinese PMI figures coupled by surging nCoV cases, in which WTI found a base at ~USD 44/bbl before recoiling to a high of USD 46.70/bbl, whilst the Brent contract bounces from an intraday low of around USD 49.50/bbl and tested USD 52/bbl to the upside, although the contracts encountered some selling pressure in recent trade but remain in solid positive territory thus far. Ahead of the OPEC confab, ING believes that “anything that falls short of the OPEC+ Joint Technical Committee recommendation of 600Mbbls/d of additional cuts over 2Q20, and extending the current deal through to year-end, will be taken as bearish.” Meanwhile, BofA Global Research lowered their 2020 WTI and Brent price forecasts by USD 8/bbl each to USD 49/bbl and USD 54/bbl respectively. Elsewhere spot gold drifts higher as the original optimism seen around the market-place fades, with the yellow metal back on a 1600/oz handle from an intraday low of ~1575/oz. Elsewhere copper initially spiked higher on further hopes of China stimulus, with prices briefly topping 2.60/lb before waning back below the figure.

Russia's Energy Minister Novak says Russia did not get a proposal from OPEC to jointly cut production by 1mln BPD, evaluating earlier JTC proposal of 600k BPD cut. (Newswires)

Russian President Putin has stated that Russia is prepared to work with OPEC+ in support of the oil market, adding that current oil prices are acceptable for Russia’s budget and economy. (Newswires) Note, while these comments are supportive ahead of this week’s OPEC meeting, they do not explicitly endorse the JTC’s recommended production cuts.

The Austrian foreign ministry is scheduled to have a conference call with the UN in Geneva and NY to further assess the risks of the OPEC meeting, according to Energy Intel's Bakr; subsequent reports states this meeting will go-ahead but a potential back up option of a teleconference has been discussed. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

South Korea Defence Ministry said North Korea fired 2 unidentified projectiles from the east coast city of Wonsan into the sea, while Japan noted it has no information that the projectiles landed in its territory or EEZ. The missiles are believed to be short-ranged. (Newswires/Yonhap) South Korea holds urgent meeting on North Korean test launch of 'short-range projectiles' suspected to be missiles, according to CNN's International Correspondent Ripley. (Twitter)

Reports noted 2 rockets landed in the ‘Concert Square’ near the US Embassy in the Baghdad green zone. (Newswires)

Turkish drone strikes in Idlib have killed 19 Syrian soldiers, meanwhile Turkey also shot down two Syrian fighter jets on Sunday. (BBC) There were prior reports that a Turkish soldier was killed and two were wounded from the shelling in Idlib, Syria. (Newswires) Turkish President Erdogan will visit Russia on March 5th, according to Turkish presidency. (Newswires) 

US 

Joe Biden won the South Carolina Democrat Primary with 48% of the votes to win 35 delegates and Bernie Sanders finished second with 20% of the votes for 13 delegates, while Pete Buttigieg has announced to suspend his presidential campaign. (Newswires)

UK publishes trade mandate for UK/US negotiations
content:
• The negotiating objectives set out that any future agreement must protect our NHS and uphold our high standards on food safety and animal welfare.
  • Government analysis published today shows that the UK economy will benefit from a £3.4 billion boost, as the trade deal will increase transatlantic trade flows by £15.3 billion.
  • The agreement will also include a chapter on digital trade, to maximise opportunities for businesses to trade digitally across the Atlantic.
  • On the UK side, talks will be overseen by Crawford Falconer, DIT’s Chief Trade Negotiation Adviser, formerly New Zealand’s Chief Negotiator and Ambassador to the WTO.
  • The US should remove the punitive tariffs imposed following the WTO’s ruling on Government subsidies to Airbus. The UK continues to support a negotiated settlement to the Airbus and Boeing.
